After viewing all the reviews, thought I would give it a go and see if I could find any issues myself. Installed fine from my package manager, configured setup for proper values. Added my off brand webcam, sound backgrounds. Did a test recording, did a few tweaks - looks nice on LINUX (Fedora) Plasma so far.
OBS performs flawlessly.
Broken, half-assed version of OBS for Windows. Doesn't even have the basic ability to change my stream's name. Another broken Linux app holding back mainstream adoption.
summary: Pale Shadow of the Windows version

description: closes itself instantly in steam deck desktop environment

Installed OK, but then... KDE updated. Bye bye installed plug ins. No informatijon on why or how to fix that I can find. Finally got the plug in working? Manually copied it to location under /usr. Update also killed my frame rate and video is now super laggy. Seems to be the pattern, apply an update, life is good. A week later apply the next updates, spend hours fixing OBS to work now and performance sucks. The functionality is outstanding....when OBS works. The source-record plug in that lets you recored each input seperately was great... while it worked. I guess this is how open source works. If I get lucky and the stars are right, when a future update fixes this, I am turning off updates. Forever. Cannot recommend this on Linux if you make your living with streaming or podcasting. It's fine if you're a hobbyist and are willing to tinker for hours after most updates. Again, that just seems to be the state of open source. I would love a one year freeze on new features foR EVERYTHING in the linux community while all the devs do is spend a year on getting their distros to interoperate with apps and for app developers to do NOTHING but bug fixes. That would be amazing.

I have not experienced any of the issues described by anyone else reviewing OBS. It works flawlessly in the Steam Deck's desktop mode. The only flaw I've experienced it that I haven't found a way to make it work during gaming mode, but I can just do what I need to on desktop anyways, so It's good.

Error upon Launching ...
"Failed to initialize video. Your GPU may not be supported, or your graphics drivers may need to be updated"

The Flatpak version of this requires ffmpeg to be installed, otherwise it will say "Failed to initialize video."
On Ubuntu, this is:
sudo apt install ffmpeg
summary: Great, if you install ffmpeg first

description: See Joshua's review of 28 Feb 2020. I used his method and OBS Studio installed without the "Failed to initialize..." error.

I needed a screen recorder for my Linux desktop. 
OBS just worked out of the box. Recorded my desktop for a demo, including adding the view from my camera facing me in one of the corners of the recording.

zu Kompliziert#

Insgesamt ist die Software der Standard wenn man Video-Streaming betreiben möche. Sie ist solide, funktioniert gut und wird gut gewartet.

Nachteilig ist, dass die Software nicht sehr intuitiv zu bedienen ist. Man muss zuerst die abstrakten Kontepte der Szenen und Quellen verstanden haben. Zudem werden diese Konzepte unabhängig von den Profilen verwaltet, was bei verschiedenen Auflösungen schlecht funktioniert. Ich würde mir eine klarere Projektverwaltung wünschen, um das ganze etwas besser zu struktirieren.

Auch die Profile sind eine Wissenschaft für sich. Es ist für den unbedarften Benutzer nicht so einfach eine gute Einstellung zu erreichen, so dass für die zur verfügingstehende Kapazität der Leitung eine optimale Übertragung erreicht.

Man muss sich schon sehr intensiv mit dem Thema beschäftigen, um damit arbeiten zu können.
Take few minutes to read wiki and understand the principles then you will enjoy it

Mit OBS-Studio hat man einen perfekten Broadcaster, Ich setze ihn parallel zum ATEM Mini Pro ein. Mit OBS kann man perfekt streamen oder die virtuelle WebCam nutzen, zum Beispiel für Meetings oder Ähnliches. Läuft bei mir unter Ubuntu-Studio und auf einem Arch Linux System. In beiden Fällen stabil und zuverlässig. Es ist auch nicht zu kompliziert, wie in anderen Rezensionen steht. Da ist jedes MS-Office-Paket komplexer. Wie mit allem, muss man sich einfach mal damit befassen.

description:
There are some bugs, like mp4 being inverted and upside down, webm being not readable by Celluloid (MPV).

But the recordr runs native Wayland now, and allows using portals for screen recording! It will probably be a good replacement for OBS in the future.

Also the custom commands are great for manual ffmpeg editing of video output.

Dentro de los programas GRATUITOS KDEnlive proporciona un equilibrio bastante bueno entre profesional y aficionado.

Es la mejor opción para hacer streams en windows y linux, he visto algunas reseñas que se quejan de que no es la última versión... a ver, obviamente si tenéis una distribución estable como debian 11 o ubuntu 22.04 tendréis la versión que se empaquetó en esa versión de la distro. Si queréis la última versión iros a una rolling release como arch.

Si te interesa grabar, producir contenido de algún tipo, lo que sea, este software no puede faltar OBS en Linux no tiene competencia a decir verdad, el resto de los programas no estan a la altura OBS es muuuuy bueno, incluso en Windows o en Mac donde hay otras opciones sigo eligiendo OBS, en Linux esperaba más problemas pero la verdad es una experiencia muy buena y estable!
No se si es culpa del sistema, obs o equipo antiguo. Pero en años anteriores lo he encontrado más estable. Este año 2023, me esta constando ajustar la configuración para grabar vídeo y audio.

description:
It is a very nice piece of software, it is easy to learn, easy to setup with Twitch.

There are some bugs though:
1. I don't know if it is because of OBS or Flatpak, but streaming a game (Transport Fever 2) while on Wayland is not possible, as soon as you get in fullscreen, the stream freezes
2. I am not able to share my entire screen (X11 or Wayland)

I hope these bugs will be fixed some time. But when you work around those bugs, you get a pretty decent experience.
